headline: Bisquick Sausage Balls
description: These Bisquick sausage balls made with baking mix, sharp Cheddar cheese, and pork sausage make a great savory party appetizer, breakfast, or brunch!

video.description: Baking mix, cheddar cheese, and sausage combine together to form delicious savory sausage balls.
video.name: Bisquick Sausage Balls

name: Bisquick Sausage Balls
recipeIngredient: 6 cups baking mix (such as Bisquick Â®)
1 pound sage-flavored pork sausage (such as Neese'sÂ® Extra Sage Sausage), at room temperature
1 pound hot pork sausage (such as Neese'sÂ® Hot Sausage), at room temperature

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 300 degrees F (150 degrees C). Grease baking sheets.
Mix baking mix, Cheddar cheese, sage-flavored pork sausage, and hot pork sausage together in a large bowl.
Form sausage mixture into 1 1/2-inch balls; arrange on the prepared baking sheets.
Bake in the preheated oven until no longer pink in the center and browned on the outside, 25 to 30 minutes.

review.reviewBody: This is so easy and such a satisfying treat.

I've been making sausage balls for many, many years. Usually during Christmas season. My family loves them. This recipe says 6 cups Bisquick. Way too much. 4 cups is plenty. Also I add about 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce. Gives them that little extra umph! ðŸ˜‹As far as the sausage brand, I prefer the homemade hot sausage from Bigs Meats and More, in McBee SC. Jimmy Deans is good too. Good quality sausage is a must. Delicious.

I have zero idea why anyone had issues with this recipe.... we don't have neeses brand sausage so I used 1 lb Jimmy deans reg and 1 lb hot, and sharp cheddar, I did add 2 TBSP milk, and raised the temp to 350 because of my oven, and they were perfect. I have tried other recipes, and this one is the best, IMO. We keep them handy almost all winter for a quick grap at any time. They heat up nicely in the microwave in seconds.
Been making them with this recipe for years,never disappoints.
My mix was looking a little dry so I added a 1/2 cup milk to make it less dry. They turned out fluffy and delicious! I will add more sausage next time.

I used to make these with a different recipe quite often. I used this All Recipes recipe this time and I kept rechecking the amount of Bisquick because it seemed like way more than I remembered. I made them anyway, (a double batch!)and they were dry dry dry and horrible. Ruined dinner and wasted a couple pounds of sausage, all that cheddar cheese, and almost three small boxes of Bisquick. Done with this site. Thanks for nothing.
I used beyond meat spicy sausage and cut the floor to 4 cups. Simply delicious vegetarian version
I always make it on holiday mornings while waiting on food for dinner. They are amazing and perfect just just grab one here and there while waiting on the big meal!
Simple and delicious!!

I made this recipe using mild sausage and sage sausage and also 1/2 of the cheese was extra sharp yellow cheddar and extra sharp white cheddar. The sausage balls came out wonderfully. I made them mostly for munchies for me & my husband and he took some to work and shared with co-workers. Reviews from them were thumbs up. They really liked them. And so did I. I'm not waiting to make them for holidays only. I will be making these year-round.

I like/love these year-round as a breakfast staple/meal, for a snack or a full breakfast meal. I did however make changes to the flavors of the sausages. I cannot handle hot sausage due to GI issues. Plus, sometimes I just want/use regular sausage instead of the sage &/or hot flavored sausages. It cannot get any better than this!!ðŸ’–
Love them

I decided to cut the recipe in half to not have so much. Well the sausage balls came out very dry and were horrible. Could not eat them. Way to doughy. I then looked at the Classic Bisquick sausage ball recipe and it has less mix and a 1/4 cup of milk which would make them much more moist. I will use that recipe from now on. This is a terrible recipe.
No I did not make any changes.
Easy and delicious!!
They r awesome I have some in the oven
I was fun to make them for New year's . For the Night
My family loves this. I've also made it with gluten free bisquick and substituted turkey or lower fat sausage.

This was my first time ever making sausage balls and they turned out delicious! Iâ€™m not known for being very adept in the kitchen so Iâ€™m writing this review to hopefully encourage others of the same level. I read through every single review first and came up with a plan based on othersâ€™ suggestions:
1. Let the sausage and cheese get to room temp first.
2. I wore latex gloves. 
3. Mixed the sausage and only 4 cups Bisquick together, incorporating just 1 cup mix at a time by folding and then kneading. I could easily see, using that method, how 6 cups would definitely work but I personally wanted a less doughy end result.
4. Once the sausage and Bisquick were fully mixed I added the cheese in 3 parts to make sure it all mixed in well.
6. Added seasoning of my choice and mixed one last time.
7. Made 3 test balls of varying thickness and tightness and baked them. Despite one review I read, the more compact balls baked up best with the looser one turning into more of a peanut shape. Golf ball size and smaller size each turned out identical. 
8. Using parchment paper, I baked the amount I needed on the top rack of oven for 25 min at 300Â°, but I may go to 27 min next time. Bottoms were brown but not over done.
9. Froze the rest by putting them on a baking sheet first in the freezer and then bagging them. 

I do not have a mixer and I do not have a rack to allow for grease to drip. So I made do without those things, but I thought they were great suggestions.

This recipe was an epic fail as written. The balls fell apart and didn't cook at 300 degrees. So here is what I did... 4 cups Bisquick, 1.5 lbs cheese, 2 lbs sausage and the addition of 2 eggs and 3/4 c. water. I also increased the baking temperature to 400 degrees for 30 minutes. They formed into balls and cooked throughout with a nice brown texture. After that, I would give it four stars!
i think the bisquick was a little much but all in all very good recipe
I add diced onions and peppers, garlic powder, paprika and 2 eggs to the recipe.... I roll them slightly larger and use them as a breakfast entree
These were really good. For an added twist use the Red Lobster cheddar bay biscuit mix. You can also use the Gluten Free mix if you are intolerant. Adds a really nice touch to these.
Have been making these for years!! Love them love them! Don't change anything, don't add anything!!
I love this! It is a favorite at Christmas with my family! I dont use the hot sausage in mine,
Six cups of bisquik? OMG, came out like cannonballs! Terrible recipe, reduce to like 2 and a half cups
Easy. A large batch. Too large for my 6 quart kitchen aid to mix

I make this recipe pretty regularly. But would add a few notes: 

I always half the recipe and just use one kind of sausage. (I do use neeseâ€™s since we are in NC and itâ€™s local) I also add milk gradually while mixing, otherwise, they are dry. Probably about 1/4 cup total but just eye ball it. You want it tacky enough to stick together but not runny in any way.
I cut cheese amount in half. Iâ€™m sure great with full amount but this works for me.

I made it exactly as written except used 1/2 of the ingredients. It was way too dry. 
I tried a second batch and doubled the sausage, added about 4 oz. more cheese and about 1/4 cup of milk. The second batch was perfect. Personally, I think that 3 cups Bisquick is a bit much and makes them too dry and they crumble too easily. Also, note that made smaller size balls (not golf ball size) which may have helped as well.
I used less bisquick.

A friend introduced me to these but wouldn't give me the recipe, so I tried this one. WE LOVE IT! Perfect for a snack, appetizer, or even a quick breakfast! I froze some and baked them a month or so later and they were still great.
I LOVE this recipe. I make it with lean ground beef instead of sausage and make a homemade marinara for dipping. Itâ€™s definitely a favorite for parties!
These are my go-to for having quick, easy, filling snacks on hand. The KitchenAid stand mixer helps tremendously for making them.

I must say that I am usually reluctant to leave a review, I was compelled to it in this case however (even signed up for an allrecipes account so that I could). The end result was absolutely inedible. WAY TOO MUCH BISQUICK in this. How ever much you make, cut the Bisquick amount in this recipe by HALF. I made the half recipe and used 3 cups per the instructions (and half the other ingredients as well). They might as well have been golf balls. Plus they were nearly impossible to "roll" into balls. Had to throw away 1/3 of the mixture as it was unusable. Will try again with a better recipe.
The proportions of this recipe are off. The ratio included here makes hockey pucks. You need much less bisquick or other baking mix. Or more sausage.

I made the sausage balls and I didnâ€™t use as much bisquick as it called for. I use about 2 and a half cups to a lb of neese hot sausage and extra sage neese sausage. And I also added just a little milk to the mixture, they turned out great!! I did a half pound of each sausage.

Uh oh! First off, this is a truckload of ingredients. I cut it in half but had WAY too much baking mix. They didnâ€™t puff up like the ones my mom made when I was a kid. Iâ€™m disappointed. And 30 min was over-cooked.
Only used hot sausage and added cayenne pepper. Taste great thank you.

Iâ€™ve made these for years and use 2 lbs of hot sausage instead of combining it. I also like to mix my cheeses. 1 lb. of yellow extra sharp and 1 lb. of Old Croc Extra Sharp White Cheddar. as oven temperatures and elevation vary, I need to bake each tray for a minimum of 52 minutes or theyâ€™re doughy inside. More than 55, and theyâ€™re dry. This is something you just have to test in your first batch.

Seemed WAYYYY too bready. I used good-quality sausage (Jimmy Dean and Tennessee Pride) good cheese....but they are dry. I may give this recipe another try, but maybe with only 4 cups of Bisquick next time.
The first batch was extremely dry so I went down to 3 1/2 cups bisquick and they are perfect!!!

Something is off with this recipe, a ratio or a step or two is left out. Just finished throwing my second batch of the this mess in the can. No matter how well i mix ingredients and compact the "balls" half way through baking i have flat burned dough and medium rare sausage.

quick treat. kids and husband love taking a few of these at a time, heating them up, and eating them for a quick snack.
(not just for breakfast)
Yay

I make these for an appetizer before Christmas dinner. We also have them for N.Y. Day bowl games and, of course, Super Bowl!
I use 1 lb. Jimmy Dean hot sausage, 2 to 2 1/4 cups Bisquick, 1 lb shredded sharp cheddar. (I find the finely shredded cheese blends in more easily, allowing the balls to hold their shape). Let the sausage come to room temperature. I also roll the balls smaller than a golf ball about 1". This will yield about 4 dozen.

Too bready
5 cups bisquick would have been better
Can hardly taste sausage
Way too much Bisquik. I'd reduce it by half. Now I am taking cakey sausage balls to a christmas party in the South. I may not be allowed back again..
I made the first two trays too big...not cooked in the middle....put foil over them...gonna cut back just a little on the bisquick I think for next batch.
These were a hit but I will cook one and continue to season as they were a bit under seasoned.
It was excellent. Fantastic for a side dish also.

My family doesn't care for sage, so I used Jimmy Dean breakfast sausage and these are very good. Also a great cold snack while riding bike. In a zip lock bag, they don't fall apart. Good snack with a bottle of water.

Iâ€™ve been make these for years. Never did them specifically for breakfast but as a hot Hor dâ€™oeuvres. Very rarely, are there any left over to have this for breakfast! This is one of my go to recipes and it never fails.

I made these as per the recipe 
Way too much bisquick, cut the bisquick in half and add 2 pounds of sausage and add any of your favorite seasoning.

DLG

Great and easy recipe!! I threw the ingredients in my mixer and then used a heaping tablespoon to keep the balls consistent. Then halfway through the cook time, I flipped the balls so they didnâ€™t get crispy on the bottom. These were a popular item at the party.
Too doughy

This is the original recipe off the Bisquick box from when i was a kid and the taste is EXACTLY what I remember. Everyone has their own preference, but my family always used the hot sausage alone. These are perfect Christmas morning when unwrapping presents. Delish!

I use 1 pound each of Jimmy Dean hot and regular sausage, and Kraft traditional shredded extra sharp cheddar. For those who say that it is too dry, you really have to work the BisquickÂ®? in one cup at a time with the cheese and donâ€™t roll the balls too big. I roll them and freeze them on cookie sheets before putting them in ZiplockÂ®? bags for the freezer, taking out what we need, cooking at 400 for ~14 minutes.
Everyone loved them! I did add a bit more cheese than the recipe called for. My family gobbled them up!

I make these for my family and everyone loves them, especially my brother. I used a sage sausage with brand name Bass Farms (NC). I use hot if I don't need a mixed batch. If I need to prepare for various tastes I cook 1/2 mild, 1/4 hot and 1/4 hot with crushed red pepper flacks
These were good but dryer than the ones my mom used to make.

I made a half batch. My wife does not like spicy sausage so I just used mild. This was the first time I used an electric mixer and it worked great. Used my dough hook and the mixture came out great. So easy I think I might make a spicy batch for myself.
I found this recipe to be too doughy. Cut the bisquick in half and only add more if too wet. I do agree preshredded cheese is too dry for this as well. Shred your own.
I followed the directions and wound up with hockey pucks. Such a disappointment. This recipe needed more liquid to make a dough.

I followed this recipe exactly, used room temperature sausage, measured everything out perfectly. After mixing and kneading until my hands hurt, there was still baking mix and cheese at the bottom of the bowl that would not incorporate into the sausage. I shoved all I could into the sausage. It made very dry balls with little flavor, but edible. I took some to my mother in laws, not knowing that she was making sausage balls, too. When I walked in and saw hers ready to go into the oven, I asked her why mine looked so different. I told her the recipe and she was shocked to see how much baking mix I put in. Hers called for 3 cups of baking mix, and made perfect little balls. This is WAY too much baking mix. Oh well, now I know!
The recipe is the exact and correct amount. I use my Kitchenaid Mixer and it turns out perfect. Hand mixing takes too long! I have followed this recipe for years. We love them!
There is no way this recipe is correct. Too much bisquick. Hard dough balls really. I luckily only made half batch.

Horrible. Fell apart in the oven and ended up with a pile of sawdust. I checked other recipes and they only call for 2cups of Bisquick. I can only assume 6 cups was a misprint. Thanks a lot! Trying to salvage the rest by adding egg and milk.
Add about 1/2 water so it would blend easier.
Too much bisquick or something they broke apart and had no flavor
6 lbs of pork sausage for sausage ball
These are a hit at EVERY gathering. Can't miss with this one.
I couldnâ€™t find sage sausage and didnâ€™t use spicy sausage. Everyone loved them the way they were with just regular sausage

The recipe is a little off in the ratio of Bisquik to the other ingredients. Following the recipe, the ingredients did not mix together in any way possible to make balls out of. It was very very dry and crumbly. The recipe includes zero liquid so I improvised and added applesauce until the consistency made ball formation possible. Sorry, I don't know exactly how much to add. 
Someone else pointed out that the recipe did not specify cooked or uncooked sausage. I found the recipe elsewhere and it did specify uncooked sausage which worked. 
After adding the applesauce the end result was very good.

I stupidly followed the directions and used 6 cups of bisquick. Too dry. Could not form a ball. I microwave some of the mixture to make it form a ball and baked it. Way too dry when they came out. Now I've got to try to figure out how to salvage all this mixture.

I grew up having these yearly around the holidays. This is the correct recipe. You have to mix it really well. I usually either allow the sausage to get to room temp or microwave it to get it warm to helpnthe mixing. I make double batches bc my family loves these (even bought a huge bowl just to make them in). My favorite mixture is 1lb of sage mixed with 1lb of hot sausage. Also, mix sausage and bisquick first then add cheese can help with the crumbles. These are always a huge hit!
Easy to make and well liked by the party group I served last weekend.

This recipe is a disaster! Way too much Bisquick; too low of an oven temperature; and too little time! Basically, you must change the ingredient ratio, the time to cook, and the oven temp to get this to work. Don't waste your time on this. Find a better recipe!
My mother has been making these since I was a very young kid. And no I am 54 and making them myself. They are always a big hit.
I followed the directions exactly, halving the ingredients.
I used cooked sausage.I added 4 eggs and a cup of milk and made them into muffins. Then, after I took them out of the oven I put a small amount of butter on them and let it melt.

Six cups of bisquick made these VERY bready. I added another lb of sausage to the second half of the mix, and they were a little sausage heavy. Iâ€™d say either decrease the baking mix to 4-5 cups OR increase the sausage to 3lbs. Flavor was good!
these tasted just like my Mom used to make. I baked them on a rack, with foil on the tray below to catch the cheese that dripped down. They were delicious!
Dryer than dry. I followed this recipe exactly, and were they bad! I think the ratio should be way less than 6 cups to 2 lbs of sausage and cheese.

I followed the recipe exactly as written for my first try, and I have to say that 6 cups Bisquick is just too much. They are very dry, and some of the sausage flavor is lost. I even added 2 eggs to mine, and they still came out dry. However, a little bit of spicy mustard fixes the problem ;) They are good, and a great appetizer or quick breakfast, but I will back off on the Bisquick next time for sure.

Great recipe! Everyone gobbles them up! However, DO NOT use aluminum foil to line your cookie sheet. It will stick to the balls and leave little aluminum pieces in them no matter how hard you try to remove them . . . We ate them anyway and you don't really taste it.

This is a good recipe but it doesn't hold together well as written. I had to add 1/2 cup milk to get the ingredients to bind together. I also tried 2 balls as a test and it was too bready. Once I added more sausage than the recipe called for and it came out great! I used a 3 cup mix / 1.5lb sausage / 1 lb cheese ratio and it was great!

I have made this recipe many times with regular Bisquick and have always rec'd rave reviews. Tried making it with gluten free Bisquick; DO NOT USE GLUTEN FREE BISQUICK!!!! Dry, powdery, terrible taste and texture....I had to throw the whole batch out.

I have made this recipe many times with regular Bisquick and have always rec'd rave reviews. Tried making it with gluten free Bisquick; DO NOT USE GLUTEN FREE BISQUICK!!!! Dry, powdery, terrible taste and texture....I had to throw the whole batch out.

These were great hot and cold. Leftovers 
were good for breakfast.

I'm not sure what happened with this recipe, but this is waaaaaay too much Bisquick. Fine if you want mildly sausage flavored mini biscuits, but these are nothing like Bisquick sausage balls I remember. I'd cut the BIsquick by a third, maybe half, but too late now...

There is nothing wrong with the proportions of this recipe, but it is very important to use a cheap, fatty sausage and have your sausage at room temperature. My grandma taught me this years ago when I insisted on using Jimmy Dean sausage, and my mix was so dry I couldn't get the balls to stick together. Next time I used a much cheaper brand of sausage and it came together perfectly. Adding the sausage at room temperature helps a lot too!
Turned out great as always. No changes. Thank you.
Awful! I wish I read the reviews first, only use like 3 cups of bisquick and add it one cup at a time. Stop adding when you are running out of moisture!!

My Meme ( Grandmother ) Made these EVERY Christmas Eve .....along with many other goodies.... These are THE BEST and Bring back so many Wonderful Memories to ME!!!! I thought I remembered the EASY Recipe but still had to look it UP! Thanks

The ratios are off...way off. These are dry... more bisquick ball than sausage ball. 
2 cups bisquick,1 lb sausage, 16 oz cheese 1/4 cup water. Perfect.
My grandson makes these with me every holiday. They're easy and delicious!
I used Heartsmart Bisquick, only used 12 oz of cheese and added 1/4 cup almond milk. I also made a healthy version with turkey sausage and fat free shredded cheddar cheese which are quite delicious.

I have been using this recipe for 40 yrs.just follow the simple directions and it it GREAT! I really wish the dummies who gave this a bad review would learn how to read! and please STOP reviewing a recipe when YOU start altering it!!...one thing I do is not to roll them too tight
